columns.text: In this problem, we will look at the relationship of the change in cashflow to the degree of operating leverage which measures how much a company's revenue is changed by a certain change in the quantity of the units sold.

Substituting the known values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
3.26&=1+\dfrac{\text{FC}}{\$78,000}\\[15 pt]
2.26&=\dfrac{FC}{\$78,000}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Using corss-multiplication to isolate the variable, we will get a fixed cost value of:

$$\begin{aligned}

\text{FC}&=2.26 \times\$78,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$176,280
\end{aligned}$$

The fixed cost in this situation is $\$176,280$

With the formula in mind, we can first solve for the percentage change in quantity:

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{Q}&=\dfrac{\text{new}-\text{old}}{\text{old}}\\

\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{Q}&=\dfrac{18,500-17,500}{17,500}\\
&=0.057
\end{aligned}$$

This means that there is a $5.7\%$ change in the quantity sold.

We can then substitute this percentage change to the formula in Step 3. We will also use the DOL value in the previous case.

$$\begin{aligned}
3.26&=\dfrac{\Delta \text{OCF}}{0.057}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Using cross multiplication to isolate the variable, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{OCF}&=3.26 \times 0.057\\[15 pt]
&=0.186
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the new value for the cashflow will be the original plus $18.6\%$
To solve for the actual value of the cashflow, we can multiply the original value to $1.186$ which represents $118.6\%$ since it increased by $18.6\%$

The new cashflow will then be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=\$78,000 \times 1.186\\[15 pt]
&=\$92,508
\end{aligned}$$

The cashflow, if the quantity is increased to $18,500$ is $\$92,508$

Finally, we will solve for the cashflow if the number of units falls to $16,500$. We will use the same process as we did in Steps 4-6.

Take the percentage change in quantity:

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{Q}&=\dfrac{16,500-17,500}{17,500}\\[15 pt]
&=-0.057
\end{aligned}$$

This means that there is a $-5.7\%$ change in the quantity sold.

We can then substitute this percentage change to the formula in Step 3. We will also use the DOL value in the previous case.

$$\begin{aligned}
3.26&=\dfrac{\Delta OCF}{-0.057}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Using cross multiplication to isolate the variable, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{OCF}&=3.26 \times -0.057\\[15 pt]
&=-0.186
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the new value for the cashflow will be the original minus $18.6\%$
To solve for the actual value of the cashflow, we can multiply the original value to $0.814$ which represents $81.4\%$ since the original decreased by $18.6\%$

The new cashflow will then be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=\$78,000 \times 0.814\\[15 pt]
&=\$63,492
\end{aligned}$$

The cashflow, if the quantity is decreased to $16,500$ is $\$63,492$
